{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3336092,"name":"Question all assumptions, search for truth.","username":"celttechie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T16:54:19.591Z","cooked":"

I’m sure what we are seeing is the effects of inertia. When accelerating our swerve drive from a standstill, it takes nearly 1.26 seconds for the motor to get up to full velocity. At the greatest error between the commanded velocity and the actual velocity, we are off by over 20 rps and approximately 1.6 volts

As I understand the phoenix6 libraries, a P term can be added to increase the voltage per error of rotations per second. If I divide 1.6 volts (the needed increase in voltage) by 20 ( the error), I get 0.08. I already HAVE a P of 0.25, so do I just add another 0.08 to it?

Am I doing this right, understanding this correctly? I have a chance to test tonight, but I was looking at the data we collected from the last attempt to get this dialed in. I should also say that when the robot is up on blocks, the drive motors do NOT lag the control at all. I’m sure this is because the weight of the robot is on the wheels and we have to overcome inertia from a standstill.

Anything else I should be doing?
